Question_1.Context: The study focused on developing a sustained release agent system (BR@MSN) to enhance the salt stress resistance of cucumber seeds and seedlings. The obtained BR@MSN agent was about 120 nm.
Question_1.Question: What was the particle size of the obtained BR@MSN agent?
Question_1.Source: The obtained BR@MSN agent was about 120 nm.

Question_2.Context: Experimental results revealed that high BR concentration exerted inhibitory effect, while low BR content posed positive influence on seedling growth.
Question_2.Question: How did low brassinolide (BR) concentration affect seedling growth?
Question_2.Source: Low BR content posed positive influence on seedling growth.

Question_3.Context: The sustained release behavior of BR@MSN followed the first-order kinetic model.
Question_3.Question: Which kinetic model best described the sustained release behavior of BR from BR@MSN?
Question_3.Source: The sustained release behavior of BR@MSN followed the first-order kinetic model.

Question_4.Context: Experimental results revealed that the foliar application of BR@MSN significantly increased the superoxide dismutase (SOD) activity of the cucumber seedlings under salt stress.
Question_4.Question: How did the foliar application of BR@MSN affect superoxide dismutase (SOD) activity?
Question_4.Source: The foliar application of BR@MSN significantly increased the SOD activity of the cucumber seedlings under salt stress.

Question_5.Context: The foliar application of BR@MSN resulted in the decrease of malondialdehyde (MDA) content in cucumber seedlings under salt stress.
Question_5.Question: How did the foliar application of BR@MSN affect malondialdehyde (MDA) content?
Question_5.Source: The foliar application of BR@MSN resulted in the decrease of MDA content in cucumber seedlings under salt stress.

Question_6.Context: Experimental results revealed that the foliar application of BR@MSN significantly increased the chlorophyll content of the cucumber seedlings under salt stress.
Question_6.Question: How did the foliar application of BR@MSN affect chlorophyll content?
Question_6.Source: The foliar application of BR@MSN significantly increased the chlorophyll content of the cucumber seedlings under salt stress.

Question_7.Context: The study revealed that the foliar application of BR@MSN enhanced the salt stress resistance of cucumber seedlings by alleviating ROS accumulation and increasing cell viability.
Question_7.Question: How did the foliar application of BR@MSN enhance salt stress resistance?
Question_7.C: By alleviating ROS accumulation and increasing cell viability
Question_7.D: By causing toxicity to cell viability
Question_7.Source: The foliar application of BR@MSN enhanced the salt stress resistance of cucumber seedlings by alleviating ROS accumulation and increasing the cell viability.

Question_8.Context: The study demonstrated that the foliar application of BR@MSN resulted in the promotion of cell viability in cucumber seedlings under salt stress.
Question_8.Question: What was the effect of the foliar application of BR@MSN on cell viability?
Question_8.Source: The foliar application of BR@MSN resulted in the promotion of cell viability in cucumber seedlings under salt stress.

Question_9.Context: The study found that the foliar application of BR@MSN significantly reduced the accumulation of superoxide anion in cucumber seedlings under salt stress.
Question_9.Question: How did the foliar application of BR@MSN affect superoxide anion accumulation?
Question_9.B: No effect on superoxide anion accumulation
Question_9.D: Caused toxicity to superoxide anion accumulation
Question_9.Source: The foliar application of BR@MSN significantly reduced the accumulation of superoxide anion in cucumber seedlings under salt stress.

Question_10.Context: Experimental results revealed that the foliar application of BR@MSN increased the superoxide dismutase (SOD) activity, decreased malondialdehyde (MDA) content, and increased chlorophyll content in cucumber seedlings under salt stress.
Question_10.Question: What were the effects of the foliar application of BR@MSN on SOD activity, MDA content, and chlorophyll content in cucumber seedlings under salt stress?
Question_10.A: Decreased SOD activity, increased MDA content, decreased chlorophyll content
Question_10.B: Increased SOD activity, decreased MDA content, increased chlorophyll content
Question_10.C: Increased SOD activity, increased MDA content, decreased chlorophyll content
Question_10.D: Decreased SOD activity, decreased MDA content, increased chlorophyll content
Question_10.Source: The foliar application of BR@MSN increased the superoxide dismutase (SOD) activity, decreased malondialdehyde (MDA) content, and increased chlorophyll content in cucumber seedlings under salt stress.
